Award.AwardTitle: Understanding How Irradiation Affects Electrochemical Charge Storage in Nanostructured Metal Oxide Electrodes
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Economic growth and population expansion have led to a rapid increase in energy consumption, intensifying the need for electrical energy storage (e.g., battery) technologies. Lithium-ion batteries are battery technologies having promise in more applications, e.g. in providing high energy and high power in electric vehicles or electrical grids. Recent studies have observed that lithium-ion battery electrode materials (such as TiO2) contain intentional structural defects exhibit enhanced electrochemical charge storage capacity. This project uses irradiation to introduce defects into TiO2 nanostructured electrodes, because irradiation is known to produce an excess of defects in a material. Confirmation of the hypothesis of enhancing battery functionality using irradiation could promote the use of intentional structural defects to profoundly transform battery research, fabrication, and applications. This project may also lead to improved battery functionality through in-service, in situ irradiation in applications subject to high radiation fields, such as satellites and high-altitude aircraft; advanced sensors for security, defense, and power production; remote warfare; nuclear energy and propulsion; and healthcare. Integrated research and education activities will have impacts on undergraduate and graduate students, as well as the general public.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The objective of this project is to determine how and by what mechanisms irradiation affects the electrochemical charge storage of nanostructured TiO2 electrodes. The project addresses the foundational science of the behavior of rechargeable battery systems under irradiation. There is currently limited knowledge of the fundamental mechanisms of irradiation effects on charge storage properties of metal oxide electrodes. This research is filling a knowledge gap in intercalation kinetics and structural evolution of metal oxide electrodes under irradiation. Studies suggest structural defects in metal oxides can enhance the material's electrochemical charge storage capacity. Since irradiation is known to produce an excess of point defects in a material, it is hypothesized that irradiation can similarly enhance the charge capacity of metal oxide electrodes. In this project, crystalline TiO2 nanotubes are proton irradiated, then undergo electrochemical cycling with Li. Recent advances in characterization techniques enable the observation of defects and nanostructure following electrochemical cycling. This project integrates experiment and modeling to obtain a fundamental understanding of irradiation effects on charge transport and structural evolution of metal oxide electrodes. Graduate student researchers are gaining technical experience with cutting-edge research equipment and techniques and working in collaboration with national laboratories. Undergraduate student researchers from the Boise State Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program are also involved. Topics from this project are being used for curriculum development and outreach programs to middle and high schools.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the NSF support, the team conducted systematic study of ion irradiation effect on structural and electrochemical properties of nanostructured metal oxide anodes for lithium ion batteries. The effect of low-energy proton irradiation on amorphous and anatase TiO2 nanotube (TiO2–NT) electrodes at both room temperature and 250°C was investigated. 250°C proton irradiation induced a disordered rutile phase transition from amorphous TiO2–NT electrode, which displayed an improved capacity by 20% compared to unirradiated control sample. The contributions from diffusion-limited intercalation and pseudocapacitive processes in the irradiated electrodes were determined from voltammetric analysis and it was found that the irradiated electrodes had more contribution from diffusion in lithium ion charge storage. For anatase TiO2–NT electrodes, it was discovered that proton irradiation enhanced their electrochemical properties ascribed to defect formation. It is shown that both anatase samples irradiated at 250?C and 25?C exhibit reduced barriers for charge transfer and increased Li+. In addition, the team examined the microstructure evolution of single crystal rutile TiO2 irradiated with 3 MeV Nb+ ions. A complex microstructure evolution was observed, marked by four distinct regions of damage. Subsequent lithiation of the irradiated sample suggests that Nb+ irradiation can improve Li+ transport and storage in two distinct ways: first by creating irradiation damage to sufficiently reduce diffusion path lengths and second by chemical doping.

This project led to new understanding of the structural and electrochemical properties of metal oxide electrodes with intentional defects through proton irradiation. The results suggest that tailoring the defect generation through ion irradiation within metal oxide electrode could present a new avenue for designing advanced electrode materials. Outreach programs related to this project were conducted to K-12 students and the local community at STEM festival, local library, high schools, Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars and Girl Scouts workshops and were well received. Research opportunities for students and strengthened collaborations with national labs were achieved. This project has provided invaluable training and skill development opportunities for four graduate students, six undergraduate students and one high school teacher, including 5 females (1 PhD student, 2 undergrads, 1 REU and 1 RET). Four peer-reviewed publications, three manuscripts in preparation, 1 PhD dissertation and 1 MS thesis are the direct products from this project.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2018
Modified by: Hui (Claire) Xiong
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: With the NSF support, the team conducted systematic study of ion irradiation effect on structural and electrochemical properties of nanostructured metal oxide anodes for lithium ion batteries. The effect of low-energy proton irradiation on amorphous and anatase TiO2 nanotube (TiO2–NT) electrodes at both room temperature and 250°C was investigated. 250°C proton irradiation induced a disordered rutile phase transition from amorphous TiO2–NT electrode, which displayed an improved capacity by 20% compared to unirradiated control sample. The contributions from diffusion-limited intercalation and pseudocapacitive processes in the irradiated electrodes were determined from voltammetric analysis and it was found that the irradiated electrodes had more contribution from diffusion in lithium ion charge storage. For anatase TiO2–NT electrodes, it was discovered that proton irradiation enhanced their electrochemical properties ascribed to defect formation. It is shown that both anatase samples irradiated at 250?C and 25?C exhibit reduced barriers for charge transfer and increased Li+. In addition, the team examined the microstructure evolution of single crystal rutile TiO2 irradiated with 3 MeV Nb+ ions. A complex microstructure evolution was observed, marked by four distinct regions of damage. Subsequent lithiation of the irradiated sample suggests that Nb+ irradiation can improve Li+ transport and storage in two distinct ways: first by creating irradiation damage to sufficiently reduce diffusion path lengths and second by chemical doping. This project led to new understanding of the structural and electrochemical properties of metal oxide electrodes with intentional defects through proton irradiation. The results suggest that tailoring the defect generation through ion irradiation within metal oxide electrode could present a new avenue for designing advanced electrode materials. Outreach programs related to this project were conducted to K-12 students and the local community at STEM festival, local library, high schools, Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars and Girl Scouts workshops and were well received. Research opportunities for students and strengthened collaborations with national labs were achieved. This project has provided invaluable training and skill development opportunities for four graduate students, six undergraduate students and one high school teacher, including 5 females (1 PhD student, 2 undergrads, 1 REU and 1 RET). Four peer-reviewed publications, three manuscripts in preparation, 1 PhD dissertation and 1 MS thesis are the direct products from this project.
